chef_bio: Shelly Nuruzzaman is a Bangladeshi chef who has been in the culinary industry for over 12 years. She specializes in traditional Bengali cuisine and is known for her unique use of spices and herbs. Her recipes are loved by many and she has a large following of food enthusiasts.

chef_recipes.cooking_method: 1. Heat oil in a pan. 2. Add onions, garlic, and ginger. 3. Add beef and cook until brown. 4. Add spices and cook until fragrant. 5. Serve hot.
1. Marinate chicken in yogurt and spices. 2. Cook rice. 3. Fry onions. 4. Layer chicken and rice in a pot. 5. Cook on low heat. 6. Serve hot.

1. Heat oil in a pan. 2. Add onions and cook until soft. 3. Add tomatoes and cook until soft. 4. Add spices and cook until fragrant. 5. Add fish and cook until done. 6. Garnish with coriander. 7. Serve hot.

chef_recipes.cooking_method: 1. Heat oil in a pan. 2. Add onions, garlic, and ginger. 3. Add beef and cook until brown. 4. Add spices and cook until fragrant. 5. Serve hot.
1. Marinate chicken in yogurt, spices, and lemon juice. 2. Roast in the oven. 3. Serve hot.

1. Heat oil in a pan. 2. Add onions and cook until soft. 3. Add tomatoes and cook until soft. 4. Add spices and cook until fragrant. 5. Add shrimp and cook until done. 6. Add coconut milk and cook for a few minutes. 7. Serve hot.

chef_bio: Asad Latif is a Bangladeshi chef who has been in the culinary industry for over 15 years. She specializes in traditional Bengali cuisine and is known for her unique use of spices and herbs. Her recipes are loved by many and she has a large following of food enthusiasts.

chef_recipes.cooking_method:
1. Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add onions and cook until golden brown.
2. Add ginger and garlic paste and cook for a minute. 
3. Add the chicken, cumin, coriander, turmeric, and salt to the pan. Cook until the chicken is browned on all sides.
4. Add the tomato and cook for 5-7 minutes until the sauce thickens.
5. Serve hot with rice or naan bread.

1. Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add onions and cook until golden brown.
2. Add ginger and garlic paste and cook for a minute. 
3. Add the mutton, cumin, coriander, turmeric, and salt to the pan. Cook until the mutton is browned on all sides.
4. Add the tomato and cook for 5-7 minutes until the sauce thickens.
5. Serve hot with rice or naan bread.

1. Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Add onions and cook until golden brown.
2. Add ginger and garlic paste and cook for a minute. 
3. Add the mutton, cumin, coriander, turmeric, and salt to the pan. Cook until the mutton is browned on all sides.
4. Add the tomato and cook for 5-7 minutes until the sauce thickens.

chef_bio: Chef Tony is a Bangladeshi chef who has been in the culinary industry for over 25 years. She specializes in traditional Bengali cuisine and is known for her unique use of spices and herbs. Her recipes are loved by many and she has a large following of food enthusiasts.

chef_recipes.cooking_method: Cook rice and lentils separately, fry onion, garlic, ginger and spices in oil, add rice and lentils and cook for a while.
Marinate mutton with spices, fry onion, garlic, ginger and spices in oil, layer rice and mutton in a pot and cook in low heat for a while.
Mix beef, onion, garlic, ginger, spices and mint leaves together, shape into kababs and grill until cooked.

chef_bio: Kiran Jethwa is a Bangladeshi chef who has been in the culinary industry for over 12 years. She specializes in traditional Bengali cuisine and is known for her unique use of spices and herbs. Her recipes are loved by many and she has a large following of food enthusiasts.

chef_recipes.cooking_method:
1. Marinate the fish with turmeric powder and salt for 10 minutes. 
2. Heat oil in a pan and fry the fish until golden brown. 
3. In the same pan, add onions and green chilies and sauté until onions are translucent. 
4. Add tomatoes, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Cook for 5 minutes. 
5. Add 1 cup of water and bring to a boil. 
6. Add the fried fish and simmer for 10 minutes. 
7. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot.

1. Heat oil in a pan and fry the chicken until golden brown. 
2. In the same pan, add onions and sauté until onions are translucent. 
3. Add tomatoes, cumin powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, garam masala powder, and salt. Cook for 5 minutes. 
4. Add 1 cup of water and bring to a boil. 
5. Simmer until the chicken is fully cooked and the gravy thickens. 
6. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve hot.

1. Heat ghee in a pan and fry the onions and green chilies until the onions are golden brown. 
2. Add ginger paste and garlic paste and sauté for 1 minute. 
3. Add beef, turmeric powder, red chili powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, garam masala powder, and salt. Cook for 10 minutes. 
4. Add 1 cup of water and bring to a boil. 
5. Simmer until the beef is fully cooked and the gravy thick

chef_bio: Feroz Khan is a Bangladeshi chef who has been in the culinary industry for over 30 years. She specializes in traditional Bengali cuisine and is known for her unique use of spices and herbs. Her recipes are loved by many and she has a large following of food enthusiasts.

chef_recipes.cooking_method:
1. Heat oil in a pan and add onion, garlic, and ginger. Fry until light brown. 
2. Add beef, turmeric powder, coriander powder, cumin powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well and cook for 10-15 minutes. 
3. Add chopped tomatoes, green chili, and garam masala. Mix well and cook for another 10-15 minutes until the beef is tender and the water dries up. 
4. Serve hot with rice or naan.

1. Wash the fish properly and marinate it with salt and turmeric powder. 
2. Heat mustard oil in a pan and fry the fish until golden brown. Take out the fish and keep it aside. 
3. In the same pan, add mustard paste, green chili, salt, and a little bit of turmeric powder. Mix well and fry for 2-3 minutes. 
4. Add water and bring it to boil. 
5. Add the fried fish and cook for 5-7 minutes. 
6. Serve hot with rice.

1. In a bowl, mix minced beef, chopped onion, chopped tomato, green chili, cilantro, coriander powder, cumin powder, red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. 
2. Add egg and bread crumbs. Mix well. 
3. Make small round-shaped kababs. 
4. Heat oil in a pan and fry the kababs until golden brown. 
5. Serve hot with green chutney.
